docs.snippet: ''I CAPULETI E I MONTECCHI'' is an opera of definite dramatic appeal that sings from beginning to end and yet somehow does not seem able to keep its hold on the affections of the public. A work of Bellini's maturity that was immediately successful...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''I CAPULETI E I MONTECCHI'' is an opera of definite dramatic appeal that sings from beginning to end and yet somehow does not seem able to keep its hold on the affections of the public. A work of Bellini's maturity that was immediately successful at its premiere in 1830, it can be rewarding for connoisseurs of his bel canto style even while exciting the uninitiated listener. It is therefore regularly revived and regularly cheered. It also is regularly forgotten. Why? In the first place, it is possible that audiences tend to be uncomfortable with a romance in which both Romeo and Juliet are portrayed by women, although the travesty role is one of opera's oldest traditions and the repertory is strewn with female singers in trousers: Cherubino, Octavian, Oscar, Zdenka and many others.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE material contained in ''Hollywood Out-Takes & Rare Footage,'' which opens today at the Waverly 1, is, with the exception of one sequence, strictly for collectors of movie trivia. The exception is a sequence shot for W.C. Fields's classic short ''The Dentist.''

headline.main: FILM: 'HOLLYWOOD OUT-TAKES,' SNIPPETS FOR TRIVIA COLLECTORS

docs.snippet: FOR almost 30 years, Art Blakey, the drummer, whose strong, steady beat and massive press rolls can turn any ensemble into a juggernaut, has been conducting a fluid, floating school of jazz called the Jazz Messengers. The Messengers, which is usua...
docs.lead_paragraph: FOR almost 30 years, Art Blakey, the drummer, whose strong, steady beat and massive press rolls can turn any ensemble into a juggernaut, has been conducting a fluid, floating school of jazz called the Jazz Messengers. The Messengers, which is usually a quintet or a sextet, has gone through a steady turnover of personnel for three decades, turning out a constant stream of new leaders of jazz groups, while maintaining a basic, readily identifiable style. ''I don't want to have a Modern Jazz Quartet,'' Mr. Blakey said the other day, referring to the group that has been made up of the same four musicians since 1955. ''I want to make room for the youngsters. Nobody else is doing it. The Messengers have always been a place to prepare for leadership, a place for training. That was the idea that Horace Silver and I had when we started the group in 1954.

docs.snippet: ''Look, there's Rex Smith - he's adorable,'' squealed a partygoer in the British Embassy rotunda the other evening. The actor was making his way through a mob of people who were standing chest to chest and balancing drinks while eating crayfish an...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Look, there's Rex Smith - he's adorable,'' squealed a partygoer in the British Embassy rotunda the other evening. The actor was making his way through a mob of people who were standing chest to chest and balancing drinks while eating crayfish and oysters from tiny plates. Earlier, at a reception in the Kennedy Center's Green Room, talk of plays, playwrights and money dominated the conversation before a screening of ''The Pirates of Penzance.'' The occasion was a fundraiser for the capital's New Playwrights' Theater, which develops new playwrights and produces new plays, with the presentation of an award to Joseph Papp, a longtime supporter of the company.

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: ''Oddities and quiddities'' is the phrase of the bibliophile Arthur A. Houghton Jr. for the melange of literary memorabilia that has just gone on display at the Grolier Club.   A meerschaum pipe formerly puffed by Amy Lowell, a silver rattle brand...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Oddities and quiddities'' is the phrase of the bibliophile Arthur A. Houghton Jr. for the melange of literary memorabilia that has just gone on display at the Grolier Club. A meerschaum pipe formerly puffed by Amy Lowell, a silver rattle brandished by the infant Percy Bysshe Shelley and brass knuckles (aluminum, actually) from the wardrobe of Erle Stanley Gardner are some of the many former possessions of famous literary folk included in the exhibition, titled ''Honour'd Relics.'' Pilgrims visiting the relics, which are to be shown through March 31, may pass for free through the club's portals, at 47 East 60th Street, between Park and Madison Avenues. The exhibition, suggested by Mr. Houghton, is open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Monday through Friday, and 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. on Saturdays. It is closed Sundays.

headline.main: RELICS OF LITERARY LIVES ON VIEW AT GROLIER CLUB

docs.lead_paragraph: ''ICAPULETI E I MONTECCHI'' is an opera of definite dramatic appeal that sings from beginning to end and yet somehow does not seem able to keep its hold on the affections of the public. A work of Bellini's maturity that was immediately successful at its premiere in 1830, it can be rewarding for connoisseurs of his bel canto style even while exciting the uninitiated listener. It is therefore regularly revived and regularly cheered. It also is regularly forgotten. Why? In the first place, it is possible that audiences tend to be uncomfortable with a romance in which both Romeo and Juliet are portrayed by women, although the travesty role is one of opera's oldest traditions and the repertory is strewn with female singers in trousers: Cherubino, Octavian, Oscar, Zdenka and many others.

docs.snippet: EVERY year Oscar de la Renta comes up with a group of free-flowing silk dresses in bold colors and patterns that would not go unnoticed in a tropical rain forest. The patterns are hand-painted and involve arresting geometric or floral patterns or ...
docs.lead_paragraph: EVERY year Oscar de la Renta comes up with a group of free-flowing silk dresses in bold colors and patterns that would not go unnoticed in a tropical rain forest. The patterns are hand-painted and involve arresting geometric or floral patterns or a combination of the two. The cuts are full and away from the body. While the designer suggests they can be worn over swimsuits, they are most popular with hostesses - and guests - at summer parties in the country.

headline.main: DE LA RENTA OFFERS SILK FOR SUMMER PARTIES

docs.snippet: S hortly after New York University's basketball team completed its 1970-71 season, Mike Muzio was quietly informed that he would succeed Lou Rossini as the Violets' coach. On a gray March day a few weeks later, he was driving along the Grand Centr...
docs.lead_paragraph: S hortly after New York University's basketball team completed its 1970-71 season, Mike Muzio was quietly informed that he would succeed Lou Rossini as the Violets' coach. On a gray March day a few weeks later, he was driving along the Grand Central Parkway with Dan Gassman, then a senior at South Side High School in Rockville Centre, L.I. That afternoon Mike Muzio had shown Dan Gassman around the University Heights campus in the Bronx, and now the coach was driving him home. As they talked, the radio was on. ''New York University,'' a voice on the radio reported, ''has decided to drop varsity basketball.'' Mike Muzio didn't know what to say. Here he was trying to persuade a basketball player to attend a college that no longer had a varsity basketball team. Without much more conversation, Mike Muzio took Dan Gassman home; the 6-foot-4-inch prospect later played at Vermont and Hofstra before attending N.Y.U. graduate school. Mike Muzio quickly drove back to the University Heights campus to talk to Ben Carnevale, then the Violets' athletic director.

docs.snippet: Covered up or bare-shouldered. Knee-baring or floor length.  Figurerevealing or supple and flowing.  These are some of the possibilities in evening clothes for the warm weather ahead. The time when women felt obliged to call up a friend to see wha...
docs.lead_paragraph: Covered up or bare-shouldered. Knee-baring or floor length. Figurerevealing or supple and flowing. These are some of the possibilities in evening clothes for the warm weather ahead. The time when women felt obliged to call up a friend to see what she was wearing to the party has indeed vanished. So has the era when everyone turned out in a reasonable facsimile of the same look at night. If anything, uniforms are even less evident in evening clothes than they are in day wear.

headline.main: FOR BALMY NIGHTS: RUFFLES OR GLITTER OR SIMPLE SHIFTS

docs.snippet: Larry Gelbart, the writer who shaped ''M*A*S*H'' into a prime-time television institution 11 years ago, is creating its successor, a new series for CBS next fall called ''Aftermash'' (''One word, no asterisks,'' he says).   Three familiar actors f...
docs.lead_paragraph: Larry Gelbart, the writer who shaped ''M*A*S*H'' into a prime-time television institution 11 years ago, is creating its successor, a new series for CBS next fall called ''Aftermash'' (''One word, no asterisks,'' he says). Three familiar actors from ''M*A*S*H,'' Harry Morgan, who plays Col. Sherman Potter, Jamie Farr, who plays Corp. Maxwell Klinger, and William Christopher, who plays the Rev. John Mulcahy, will star in the new series, a comedy to be set in a stateside veterans' hospital after the Korean War. Mr. Gelbart will develop the series, but he plans to write only the first three episodes. ''That's it,'' he whispers with finality. ''I haven't got the legs or the heart to do it entirely. My idea is to use the first three as a transition from what was to what will be.''
